The molecular weight distribution of lot 302212, determined by sedimentation equilibrium in the ultracentrifuge by the method of Scholte, ranged from 197,100 to 394,000 with a maximum frequency of 280,000).
Infant formula: To one-third of the formula, no carrageenan was added; to one-third, 300 mg of native carrageenan per liter were added, an amount equal to the highest level used in commercially available formulas for human infants; and to the remaining one-third, 1500 mg of native carrageenan per liter were added.
Feeding of each infant baboon: five times per day for the first 14 days; four times for the next 14 days; three times for the next 56 days; and two times for the 28 days until 112 days of age. No other fluid or food was provided.

In an effort to reasonably approximate a typical North American high-fat diet, a basal diet (control) was formulated with poultry meal (45 %), casein (4 %) and an exogenous animal and vegetable fat blend. Experimental diets were formulated by replacing the normal corn starch in the basal diet with 10% granular high amylose corn starch (GCS), granular potato starch (GPS; Avebe), retrograded high amylose corn starch (RCS), GG (SUPERCOLw-Guar Gum; Hercules Incorporated Aqualon Division) or cellulose.

column10: Guar gum. Three diets. 1) basal diet with corn starch, crystalline cellulose, saccharose and soybean oil; 2) basal diet plus 0.5% Guar gum; 3) basal diet plus 1.0% Guar gum. All animals were included in three experimental periods (3×3 Latin Square design). The treatments were assigned randomly (two pigs per treatment) in each experimental period. Each period had a 7-days duration, 5 days of adaptation to the diet and 2 days to collect samples of ileal content. The pigs were fed equal amounts at 07:00 and 19:00 h.
